title: Was the Eastern Roman Empire a vassal state to the Hunnic Empire? - Quora

response.answer_text: People have a very distorted image today, about notions like “vassality” and tribute, which make it impossible to transmit appropriate information. Know that in the middle ages, vassality was not a “directed graph”, like in “everyone is vassal of someone alone”. They changed vassality relations like socks, had sometimes multiple alliances, in particular with lords who were in conflict. Sometimes you had circular vassality relations too. Now going down to antiquity: knowing that the Roman Empire was the proud winner that it was, one would believe that everyone feared them and payed to their richness. Not really. They also had a wide space of border with what they called barbar nations — which were not always as barbar as that — and had complex relations with them, between wars and cointeresting them to protect the borders. It happened also that they simply were defeated by the barbars and forced to play tribute — and they did. Until, sooner or later — sometimes it took more than a century — they succeeded to defeat those neighbours. I know that this happened with Ilyrians, then with Dacians, with Gauls probably too, before Caesar. Similarly, the Eastern Roman Empire was much more than the Italian one, in a dramatic vortex of strong military civilisations compared to which it was often weaker. But they had the culture, the memory, the diplomacy. However, several of the Asian tribes which arrived with immense military success in Europe, were held at a distance … by paying tribute: this holds for Huns, as it did for Bulgars and Avars. Goths were enemies, then seeked refuge in the Empire, from the Huns. Furhter east, the Khazars received high tribute in gold for not alying to the Arabs and attacking the Empire, but rather protecting its borders… So paying the barbars either because of having been temporarily defeated by them, or in foresight, as a “service-payment” for protecting the borders, was very frequent in those times. You call it vassality? Your pleasure — the name did not exist then.
